articles.headline: Mansions Go Under the Gavel
articles.snippet: With the real estate market in the doldrums, many owners of multimillion-dollar homes are being pushed by creditors or courts to use auctions.
articles.abstract: With the real estate market in the doldrums, many owners of multimillion-dollar homes are being pushed by creditors or courts to use auctions.
articles.lead_paragraph: LITTLE TORCH KEY, Fla.  Jack Warner leaned against his home bar and checked his watch before resuming his blank stare at the white tent outside his multimillion-dollar dream house, with its swimming pool and views of the Florida gulf, soon to be sold at auction.

articles.headline: It’s Time to Stay the Courier
articles.snippet: Instead of trying to find short-term solutions to its financial crisis, perhaps the Postal Service should change its business model.
articles.abstract: Instead of trying to find short-term solutions to its financial crisis, perhaps the Postal Service should change its business model.
articles.lead_paragraph: So you think your business has problems.

articles.headline: As Economy Turns, Washington Looks Better
articles.snippet: The so-called Great Recession seems to be at or near an end because of efforts by policy makers.
articles.abstract: The so-called Great Recession seems to be at or near an end because of efforts by policy makers.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  What if in the end they got it right?

articles.headline: At Fox and MSNBC, Hosts Refire the Insult Machines
articles.snippet: General Electric and the News Corporation are trying to salvage a cease-fire between MSNBC and the Fox News Channel.
articles.abstract: General Electric and the News Corporation are trying to salvage a cease-fire between MSNBC and the Fox News Channel.
articles.lead_paragraph: Executives at two of the country’s largest media companies are still trying to salvage what was essentially a cease-fire between MSNBC and the Fox News Channel.

articles.headline: Professor Main Target of Assault on Twitter
articles.snippet: The cyberattacks on popular Web services disrupted the lives of hundreds of millions of Internet users to get to one man from the republic of Georgia.
articles.abstract: The cyberattacks on popular Web services disrupted the lives of hundreds of millions of Internet users to get to one man from the republic of Georgia.
articles.lead_paragraph: The cyberattacks Thursday and Friday on Twitter and other popular Web services disrupted the lives of hundreds of millions of Internet users, but the principal target appeared to be one man: a 34-year-old economics professor from the republic of Georgia.
articles.byline: By Jenna Wortham and Andrew E. Kramer

articles.headline: Beyond Beltway, Health Debate Turns Hostile
articles.snippet: Members of Congress have been shouted down, hanged in effigy and taunted by crowds at town hall meetings on health care.
articles.abstract: Members of Congress have been shouted down, hanged in effigy and taunted by crowds at town hall meetings on health care.
articles.lead_paragraph: The bitter divisions over an overhaul of the health care system have exploded at town-hall-style meetings over the last few days as members of Congress have been shouted down, hanged in effigy and taunted by crowds. In several cities, noisy demonstrations have led to fistfights, arrests and hospitalizations.

articles.headline: Attacks on Homeless Bring Push on Hate Crime Laws
articles.snippet: With a surge in unprovoked attacks against the homeless, some states are considering legislation to treat such assaults as hate crimes.
articles.abstract: With a surge in unprovoked attacks against the homeless, some states are considering legislation to treat such assaults as hate crimes.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  With economic troubles pushing more people onto the streets in the last few years, law enforcement officials and researchers are seeing a surge in unprovoked attacks against the homeless, and a number of states are considering legislation to treat such assaults as hate crimes.

articles.headline: Paulson’s Calls to Goldman Tested Ethics
articles.snippet: Questions linger about former Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr.’s relationship with the investment bank.
articles.abstract: Questions linger about former Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr.’s relationship with the investment bank.
articles.lead_paragraph: Before he became President George W. Bush’s Treasury secretary in 2006, Henry M. Paulson Jr. agreed to hold himself to a higher ethical standard than his predecessors. He not only sold all his holdings in Goldman Sachs, the investment bank he had run, but also specifically said that he would avoid any substantive interaction with Goldman executives for his entire term unless he first obtained an ethics waiver from the government.
articles.byline: By Gretchen Morgenson and Don Van Natta Jr

articles.headline: For Private Equity, a Very Public Disaster
articles.snippet: Cerberus had high hopes for Chrysler. But by this spring, a $7.4 billion stake had dwindled to $1.4 billion.
articles.abstract: Cerberus had high hopes for Chrysler. But by this spring, a $7.4 billion stake had dwindled to $1.4 billion.
articles.lead_paragraph: FOR Steve Feinberg, the onetime owner of Chrysler, the past year has been a crawl toward defeat. He lost billions of dollars. He lost prestige. He lost his privacy. And he ended up a ward and supplicant of the federal government.

articles.headline: And You Thought a Prescription Was Private
articles.snippet: Prescriptions and the information on them are bought and sold in a murky marketplace, often without the patients’ knowledge or permission.
articles.abstract: Prescriptions and the information on them are bought and sold in a murky marketplace, often without the patients’ knowledge or permission.
articles.lead_paragraph: MORE than 10 years after she tried without success to have a baby, Marcy Campbell Krinsk is still receiving painful reminders in her mail. The ads and promotions started after she bought fertility drugs at a pharmacy in San Diego.

articles.headline: Pakistan Says Feud Kills a Top Militant
articles.snippet: Officials said they had received information that a militant commander had been killed in a struggle over power in the Taliban.
articles.abstract: Officials said they had received information that a militant commander had been killed in a struggle over power in the Taliban.
articles.lead_paragraph: PESHAWAR, Pakistan  Pakistani officials said they had received information on Saturday that a ranking militant commander had been killed in a power struggle over who would take control of the Pakistani Taliban.
articles.byline: By Ismail Khan and Sabrina Tavernise

articles.headline: Imperfect Politics of Pay
articles.snippet: An examination of the executive compensation bill that recently passed in the House raises questions about whether it will, if enacted, have the desired effect.
articles.abstract: An examination of the executive compensation bill that recently passed in the House raises questions about whether it will, if enacted, have the desired effect.
articles.lead_paragraph: THE executive compensation bill that the House passed just before the August recess was advertised as the first in a series of government safeguards to prevent risky, me-first maneuverings around executive pay in corporate America. It’s supposed to correct wrongheaded structures that generated untold millions for aggressive managers and monster losses for unwitting taxpayers.

articles.headline: There’s an App for That. But a Revenue Stream?
articles.snippet: Media companies know that they need a presence on smartphones, but they are still navigating financial questions.
articles.abstract: Media companies know that they need a presence on smartphones, but they are still navigating financial questions.
articles.lead_paragraph: Media brands are jumping onto the iPhone. USA Today? There’s an app for that. “The Rachel Maddow Show”? “Entertainment Tonight”? Public radio? Yes, yes and yes, there are apps for those.

articles.headline: Seattle Paper Is Resurgent as a Solo Act
articles.snippet: The newspaper has picked up most of its Web-only rival’s print subscribers and kept them, and says daily circulation has risen more than 30 percent.
articles.abstract: The newspaper has picked up most of its Web-only rival’s print subscribers and kept them, and says daily circulation has risen more than 30 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE  When The Seattle Times became this city’s only surviving daily newspaper in March, even The Times itself could not muster much optimism about its chances.

articles.headline: Arrest in China Rattles Backers of Legal Rights
articles.snippet: China’s legal rights movement, already reeling from a crackdown on lawyers, has been shaken by the detention of Xu Zhiyong, a respected rights defender.
articles.abstract: China’s legal rights movement, already reeling from a crackdown on lawyers, has been shaken by the detention of Xu Zhiyong, a respected rights defender.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING  China’s nascent legal rights movement, already reeling from a crackdown on crusading lawyers, the kidnapping of defense witnesses and the shuttering of a prominent legal clinic, has been shaken by the detention of a widely respected rights defender who has been incommunicado since the police led him away from his apartment 12 days ago.

articles.headline: For Murdoch, It’s Try, Try Again
articles.snippet: The owner of News Corporation says he wants to go against the grain and “charge for all our news Web sites.”
articles.abstract: The owner of News Corporation says he wants to go against the grain and “charge for all our news Web sites.”
articles.lead_paragraph: Does Rupert Murdoch have one more revolution in him?

articles.headline: An Online Market Flourishes in China
articles.snippet: Millions of people in China — recent graduates, shopkeepers and retirees — are using Taobao to sell things like clothes, phones and toys.
articles.abstract: Millions of people in China — recent graduates, shopkeepers and retirees — are using Taobao to sell things like clothes, phones and toys.
articles.lead_paragraph: YIWU, China  In the months leading up to his college graduation in June, Yang Fugang spent most of his days away from campus, managing an online store that sells cosmetics, shampoo and other goods he often buys from local factories.

articles.headline: Breakfast Can Wait. The Day’s First Stop Is Online.
articles.snippet: Technology has shaken up morning routines — people are increasingly waking up and lunging for their laptops.
articles.abstract: Technology has shaken up morning routines — people are increasingly waking up and lunging for their laptops.
articles.lead_paragraph: Karl and Dorsey Gude of East Lansing, Mich., can remember simpler mornings, not too long ago. They sat together and chatted as they ate breakfast. They read the newspaper and competed only with the television for the attention of their two teenage sons.

articles.headline: News Site Keeps Focus on Town’s Recession
articles.snippet: MSNBC.com has ensconced itself in one city in Indiana and documented how that city grappled with the economic downturn.
articles.abstract: MSNBC.com has ensconced itself in one city in Indiana and documented how that city grappled with the economic downturn.
articles.lead_paragraph: Like other media organizations this year, MSNBC.com wanted to show the wrath of the recession at the kitchen table level. So it began what is one of the most unusual experiments in online journalism to date: it ensconced itself in one city in Indiana and documented how that city grappled with the economic downturn.

articles.headline: Effort to Rein In Wall Street Pay Hits New Hurdle
articles.snippet: Guaranteed bonuses at big banks have made a comeback, despite the public outcry over the use of taxpayer money.
articles.abstract: Guaranteed bonuses at big banks have made a comeback, despite the public outcry over the use of taxpayer money.
articles.lead_paragraph: A guaranteed bonus might strike many people as a contradiction in terms. But on Wall Street, banks have become so eager to lure and keep top deal makers and traders that they are reviving the practice of offering ironclad, multimillion-dollar payouts  guaranteed, no matter how an employee performs.

articles.headline: Mentally Ill Offenders Strain Juvenile System
articles.snippet: Cash-starved states are increasingly relying on the prison system to handle young offenders with mental illnesses, who often need therapy more than punishment.
articles.abstract: Cash-starved states are increasingly relying on the prison system to handle young offenders with mental illnesses, who often need therapy more than punishment.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKLIN FURNACE, Ohio  The teenager in the padded smock sat in his solitary confinement cell here in this state’s most secure juvenile prison and screamed obscenities.

articles.headline: U.S. to Hunt Down Afghan Drug Lords Tied to Taliban
articles.snippet: U.S. commanders say the addition of drug traffickers to a “kill or capture” list is legal and a key part of a plan to disrupt the flow of drug money to the Taliban.
articles.abstract: U.S. commanders say the addition of drug traffickers to a “kill or capture” list is legal and a key part of a plan to disrupt the flow of drug money to the Taliban.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Fifty Afghans believed to be drug traffickers with ties to the Taliban have been placed on a Pentagon target list to be captured or killed, reflecting a major shift in American counternarcotics strategy in Afghanistan, according to a Congressional study to be released this week.

articles.headline: Sectarian Bombings Pulverize a Village in Iraq
articles.snippet: In the most devastating attack, a pair of flatbed trucks packed with bombs exploded simultaneously in a village near Mosul.
articles.abstract: In the most devastating attack, a pair of flatbed trucks packed with bombs exploded simultaneously in a village near Mosul.
articles.lead_paragraph: BAGHDAD  The entire village was gone. Local television broadcast scenes of homes reduced to heaps of rubble mixed with bed frames, mattresses, furniture and bloodstained pillows. A villager cried into the camera, “Look, Mr. Prime Minister and Mr. Interior Minister, where is the security that you speak about?”

articles.headline: G.M. to Cut the Ribbon for Its Store on eBay
articles.snippet: Vehicles will not be auctioned to the highest bidder but rather listed at a price equal to G.M.’s supplier price.
articles.abstract: Vehicles will not be auctioned to the highest bidder but rather listed at a price equal to G.M.’s supplier price.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT  General Motors will begin selling new cars and trucks on the auction Web site eBay in an attempt to regain some of its lost market share in the United States.
